[cron:8b380d56-7314-4ba9-b4c4-ea11d3e5ca6f PR Review Patrol (High Frequency)] PR patrol for bills-bot.

Repo: /home/bill/.openclaw/workspace-build/bills-bot/

‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL RULE: Only check PRs authored by Bill (BillChirico) or by Pip Build / sub-agents. Do NOT check, fix, or address PRs from anyone else (other contributors, bots like coderabbitai, dependabot[bot], renovate[bot]) unless Bill has explicitly told you to.

Do this each run:
1) List open PRs in BillChirico/bills-bot.
2) Filter to ONLY Bill's PRs and Pip Build's PRs. Skip everything else.
3) For eligible PRs, count unresolved review threads.
4) If no unresolved threads on eligible PRs: respond exactly `NO_REPLY`.
5) If unresolved threads exist:
   - Spawn ONE sub-agent PER PR (parallel), never batch PRs together.
   - Use agentId `build`, model `anthropic/claude-opus-4-6`, thinking `high`.
   - Include full unresolved thread details (thread id, file path, line, issue summary).
   - Instruct spawned agents to read and follow CODING.md, fix all review comments (including nitpicks unless nonsensical/breaking/redundant), run tests/coverage, resolve threads.
   - Instruct spawned agents NOT to post PR summary comments unless Bill explicitly asks.
   - Have spawned agents report completion summary back to parent agent.
   - After spawning, send Bill a concise Discord DM status update:
     - channel: discord
     - target: user:191633014441115648
     - accountId: pip-build
     - include PR numbers and unresolved thread counts.
6) If any spawned run fails/stalls, note it in DM and respawn once.

Keep updates concise and action-oriented.
Current time: Tuesday, February 17th, 2026 ‚Äî 11:49 AM (America/New_York)

üß© Analysis chain üåê Web query: `jsonwebtoken npm algorithm confusion vulnerability HS256` üí° Result: ‚ÄúJWT algorithm confusion (RS256 ‚Üí HS256)‚Äù is a **misconfiguration/validation flaw pattern**, not typically a single ‚ÄúHS256 bug‚Äù in `jsonwebtoken` itself: if a server **expects RS256** but **doesn‚Äôt enforce the allowed algorithms**, an attacker who can obtain the **public key** can change the JWT header to `alg: HS256` and then **HMAC-sign with the public key as the ‚Äúsecret‚Äù**, potentially getting the token accepted. OWASP explicitly calls out this risk pattern and notes how Node‚Äôs `jsonwebtoken` API shape can make this mistake easy if you don‚Äôt pin algorithms. [1] Separately, `jsonwebtoken` (npm) **did have** a real verification bypass: **versions ‚â§ 8.5.1** could accept **unsigned** tokens in a specific scenario (no `algorithms` specified + a **falsy** key/secret), due to defaulting to `none`; this was **patched in 9.0.0** (removing default support for `none`). [2] Also, people often mix up `jsonwebtoken` with the similarly named package `json-web-token` (npm), which has a published advisory for an **algorithm-confusion vulnerability** (CVE-2023-48238 / GHSA-4xw9-cx39-r355). [3] **What to do (for `jsonwebtoken`):** - **Upgrade to `jsonwebtoken` ‚â• 9.0.0**. [2] - In `jwt.verify`, **explicitly whitelist algorithms** (e.g. only `['RS256']`) rather than relying on defaults. [1] - Don‚Äôt allow both **HS\*** and **RS\***/**ES\*** for the same verifier, and don‚Äôt reuse/publicly expose key material in a way that could be misused as an HMAC secret (the classic RS256‚ÜíHS256 confusion condition). [1] **Sources:** [1] OWASP WSTG ‚Äì Testing JSON Web Tokens (algorithm confusion / RS256‚ÜíHS256) ([owasp.org](https://owasp.org/www-project-web-security-testing-guide/latest/4-Web_Application_Security_Testing/06-Session_Management_Testing/10-Testing_JSON_Web_Tokens?utm_source=openai)) [2] GitHub Security Advisory: `auth0/node-jsonwebtoken` GHSA-qwph-4952-7xr6 (‚â§8.5.1, patched 9.0.0) ([github.com](https://github.com/auth0/node-jsonwebtoken/security/advisories/GHSA-qwph-4952-7xr6?utm_source=openai)) [3] GitHub Security Advisory: `joaquimserafim/json-web-token` GHSA-4xw9-cx39-r355 (algorithm confusion) ([github.com](https://github.com/joaquimserafim/json-web-token/security/advisories/GHSA-4xw9-cx39-r355?utm_source=openai)) Citations: - 1: https://owasp.org/www-project-web-security-testing-guide/latest/4-Web_Application_Security_Testing/06-Session_Management_Testing/10-Testing_JSON_Web_Tokens?utm_source=openai - 2: https://github.com/auth0/node-jsonwebtoken/security/advisories/GHSA-qwph-4952-7xr6?utm_source=openai - 3: https://github.com/joaquimserafim/json-web-token/security/advisories/GHSA-4xw9-cx39-r355?utm_source=openai --- üèÅ Script executed: ```shell # Check if the file exists and matches the snippet if [ -f "src/api/middleware/oauth.js" ]; then echo "=== File exists, checking lines 29-35 ===" sed -n '25,40p' src/api/middleware/oauth.js else echo "File not found" fi ``` Repository: BillChirico/bills-bot Length of output: 418 ---
**Explicitly specify JWT algorithms to prevent algorithm confusion attacks.** `jwt.verify(token, sessionSecret)` without an `algorithms` option leaves the verification vulnerable to algorithm confusion attacks. This is a real attack pattern where an attacker can change the JWT header algorithm (e.g., from RS256 to HS256) and forge signatures if the verification doesn't enforce which algorithms are acceptable. OWASP explicitly recommends always specifying allowed algorithms.
üîí Proposed fix ```diff - const decoded = jwt.verify(token, sessionSecret); + const decoded = jwt.verify(token, sessionSecret, { algorithms: ['HS256'] }); ```

üß© Analysis chain üåê Web query: `jsonwebtoken npm algorithm confusion vulnerability HS256` üí° Result: ‚ÄúJWT algorithm confusion (RS256 ‚Üí HS256)‚Äù is a **misconfiguration/validation flaw pattern**, not typically a single ‚ÄúHS256 bug‚Äù in `jsonwebtoken` itself: if a server **expects RS256** but **doesn‚Äôt enforce the allowed algorithms**, an attacker who can obtain the **public key** can change the JWT header to `alg: HS256` and then **HMAC-sign with the public key as the ‚Äúsecret‚Äù**, potentially getting the token accepted. OWASP explicitly calls out this risk pattern and notes how Node‚Äôs `jsonwebtoken` API shape can make this mistake easy if you don‚Äôt pin algorithms. [1] Separately, `jsonwebtoken` (npm) **did have** a real verification bypass: **versions ‚â§ 8.5.1** could accept **unsigned** tokens in a specific scenario (no `algorithms` specified + a **falsy** key/secret), due to defaulting to `none`; this was **patched in 9.0.0** (removing default support for `none`). [2] Also, people often mix up `jsonwebtoken` with the similarly named package `json-web-token` (npm), which has a published advisory for an **algorithm-confusion vulnerability** (CVE-2023-48238 / GHSA-4xw9-cx39-r355). [3] **What to do (for `jsonwebtoken`):** - **Upgrade to `jsonwebtoken` ‚â• 9.0.0**. [2] - In `jwt.verify`, **explicitly whitelist algorithms** (e.g. only `['RS256']`) rather than relying on defaults. [1] - Don‚Äôt allow both **HS\*** and **RS\***/**ES\*** for the same verifier, and don‚Äôt reuse/publicly expose key material in a way that could be misused as an HMAC secret (the classic RS256‚ÜíHS256 confusion condition). [1] **Sources:** [1] OWASP WSTG ‚Äì Testing JSON Web Tokens (algorithm confusion / RS256‚ÜíHS256) ([owasp.org](https://owasp.org/www-project-web-security-testing-guide/latest/4-Web_Application_Security_Testing/06-Session_Management_Testing/10-Testing_JSON_Web_Tokens?utm_source=openai)) [2] GitHub Security Advisory: `auth0/node-jsonwebtoken` GHSA-qwph-4952-7xr6 (‚â§8.5.1, patched 9.0.0) ([github.com](https://github.com/auth0/node-jsonwebtoken/security/advisories/GHSA-qwph-4952-7xr6?utm_source=openai)) [3] GitHub Security Advisory: `joaquimserafim/json-web-token` GHSA-4xw9-cx39-r355 (algorithm confusion) ([github.com](https://github.com/joaquimserafim/json-web-token/security/advisories/GHSA-4xw9-cx39-r355?utm_source=openai)) Citations: - 1: https://owasp.org/www-project-web-security-testing-guide/latest/4-Web_Application_Security_Testing/06-Session_Management_Testing/10-Testing_JSON_Web_Tokens?utm_source=openai - 2: https://github.com/auth0/node-jsonwebtoken/security/advisories/GHSA-qwph-4952-7xr6?utm_source=openai - 3: https://github.com/joaquimserafim/json-web-token/security/advisories/GHSA-4xw9-cx39-r355?utm_source=openai --- üèÅ Script executed: ```shell # Check if the file exists and matches the snippet if [ -f "src/api/middleware/oauth.js" ]; then echo "=== File exists, checking lines 29-35 ===" sed -n '25,40p' src/api/middleware/oauth.js else echo "File not found" fi ``` Repository: BillChirico/bills-bot Length of output: 418 ---
**Explicitly specify JWT algorithms to prevent algorithm confusion attacks.** `jwt.verify(token, sessionSecret)` without an `algorithms` option leaves the verification vulnerable to algorithm confusion attacks. This is a real attack pattern where an attacker can change the JWT header algorithm (e.g., from RS256 to HS256) and forge signatures if the verification doesn't enforce which algorithms are acceptable. OWASP explicitly recommends always specifying allowed algorithms.
üîí Proposed fix ```diff - const decoded = jwt.verify(token, sessionSecret); + const decoded = jwt.verify(token, sessionSecret, { algorithms: ['HS256'] }); ```

PR Review Fix: bills-bot PR #74 ‚Äî feat: per-guild configuration (multi-tenancy)

**Read CODING.md first** ‚Äî follow all mandatory workflow rules.

Repo: /home/bill/.openclaw/workspace-build/bills-bot/
Branch: feat/per-guild-config
PR: https://github.com/BillChirico/bills-bot/pull/74

There are **4 unresolved review threads** to fix. Address ALL of them:

---

**Thread 1 ‚Äî src/modules/ai.js:52** (cursor/bugbot, Medium)
"AI history settings ignore guild overrides"
`getHistoryLength(guildId)` and `getHistoryTTLDays(guildId)` were made guild-aware, but the module's internal call paths still invoke them without a `guildId`. This makes AI history limit and TTL behavior continue using global defaults, so guild-specific overrides in `config` are silently ignored.
Locations: src/modules/ai.js#L33-L53, src/modules/ai.js#L30-L32

---

**Thread 2 ‚Äî src/modules/memory.js:142** (cursor/bugbot, Medium)
"Memory feature config remains globally scoped"
`getMemoryConfig(guildId)` now supports per-guild config, but callers in `memory.js` still call `getMemoryConfig()` without passing any guild context. That keeps memory enablement and limits effectively global, so guild-specific `memory.*` overrides are not applied at runtime.
Locations: src/modules/memory.js#L139-L143, src/modules/memory.js#L164-L165, src/modules/memory.js#L179-L180

---

**Thread 3 ‚Äî src/index.js:375** (cursor/bugbot, Medium)
"Guild config changes trigger global transport reloads"
The `onConfigChange` listeners for `logging.database*` ignore the new `guildId` argument, so guild-scoped updates now run global transport reconfiguration logic. A per-guild write to `logging.database.*` can repeatedly recreate `pgTransport` even when global logging config did not change.
Locations: src/index.js#L364-L372, src/modules/config.js#L245-L256

---

**Thread 4 ‚Äî src/modules/threading.js:67** (cursor/bugbot, Low)
"Thread eviction ignores guild-specific reuse windows"
`getThreadConfig` is now guild-aware, but eviction still uses a config read without guild context, so expiry falls back to global `reuseWindowMs`. Threads in guilds with custom reuse windows can be evicted too early or retained too long.
Location: src/modules/threading.js#L64-L68

---

**Instructions:**
1. Checkout branch `feat/per-guild-config`, pull latest
2. Fix ALL 4 issues ‚Äî thread guildId through to internal callers, add guildId guards for config change listeners
3. Run tests (`pnpm test`) and ensure they pass. Add/update tests as needed for the new guild-aware call paths
4. Use conventional commits (e.g., `fix: thread guildId through AI/memory/threading internal callers`)
5. Push fixes to the branch

PR Review Fix: bills-bot PR #73 ‚Äî feat: guild admin authentication & authorization

**Read CODING.md first** ‚Äî follow all mandatory workflow rules.

Repo: /home/bill/.openclaw/workspace-build/bills-bot/
Branch: feat/guild-admin-auth
PR: https://github.com/BillChirico/bills-bot/pull/73

There are **3 unresolved review threads** to fix. Address ALL of them:

---

**Thread 1 ‚Äî src/api/routes/auth.js:136** (claude, Critical)
"Discord access token stored in plaintext JWT"
The Discord `accessToken` is embedded in the JWT payload. JWTs are signed but NOT encrypted ‚Äî anyone who receives this token can decode it with base64 and extract the raw Discord access token. This grants full `identify guilds` scope access to the user's Discord account.
Fix: Use server-side session store. Store the `accessToken` in a server-side session (e.g., in-memory Map keyed by userId) and only put the userId in the JWT. Look up the access token server-side when needed. Remove accessToken from JWT payload.

---

**Thread 2 ‚Äî src/api/routes/auth.js:28** (claude, Warning)
"oauthStates map can grow unboundedly"
`cleanExpiredStates()` is only called when a new `/discord` redirect is initiated. If OAuth is rarely used, expired state entries accumulate indefinitely ‚Äî slow memory leak.
Fix: Either run cleanup on an interval (e.g., `setInterval(cleanExpiredStates, 5 * 60 * 1000)`) with proper cleanup in `stopServer`, OR also call `cleanExpiredStates()` at the start of the callback handler, OR use a bounded data structure.

---

**Thread 3 ‚Äî src/api/routes/guilds.js:89** (claude, Warning)
"fetchUserGuilds called on every admin-gated request"
Every request to a `requireGuildAdmin`-protected endpoint calls `fetchUserGuilds`, which makes a full HTTP round-trip to Discord's API. Under moderate traffic, this will hit Discord rate limits.
Fix: Add a short-lived cache (60-120s TTL) keyed by userId to avoid redundant fetches.

---

**Instructions:**
1. Checkout branch `feat/guild-admin-auth`, pull latest
2. Fix ALL 3 issues
3. Run tests (`pnpm test`) and ensure they pass. Add/update tests as needed
4. Use conventional commits (e.g., `fix: store Discord access token server-side instead of in JWT`)
5. Push fixes to the branch
6. Resolve the 3 review threads on GitHub using `gh api` (POST graphql mutation to resolve each thread)
7. Do NOT post a PR summary comment unless Bill explicitly asks
8. Report completion summary back here
